summary: This is a status update memorandum from the Federal Bureau of Prisons (FBOP) to the Office of Inspector General (OIG) regarding the implementation of recommendations from a June 2023 OIG report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The document details FBOP's responses to eight specific recommendations, primarily focusing on drafting new guidance and modifying program statements related to inmate housing, suicide watch procedures, staffing, cell searches, and security camera systems. It includes extensive attachments of training materials (Back 2 Basics curriculum) and internal analyses (staffing risk assessment, incentives playbook). This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) internal guidance document titled 'Applying Criteria to Identify High-Risk Groups of Employees'. It provides a checklist and methodology for BOP leaders to identify employee groups at high risk of leaving the agency, in order to target retention incentives effectively. It is not directly related to the Epstein case but is part of the released document set. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) internal guidance document containing checklists, templates, and strategies for employee retention, morale-boosting, communication, and team-building. It includes criteria for identifying high-risk employee groups, appreciation techniques, newsletter templates, and roundtable facilitation guides. It does not directly mention Jeffrey Epstein or his case. This is a U.S. Department of Justice, Bureau of Prisons (BOP) contract (award number 15BNAS21D00000114) with ANUUS ASSOCIATES, INC. for Employee Assistance Program (EAP) and Work/Life services. It is a firm-fixed-price contract with a base period and multiple option years, totaling an estimated $3,411,030. The document outlines the schedule, clauses, and security requirements for handling DOJ information. This document is a section of a Department of Justice (DOJ) contract detailing extensive information technology security requirements for contractors handling DOJ information. It covers compliance with federal security standards, breach reporting procedures, cloud computing rules, and requirements for safeguarding personally identifiable information (PII). This document is a section of a federal contract, specifically pages 15-20 of a 24-page contract, containing standard Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR) clauses and Bureau of Prisons (BOP) specific clauses. It details requirements for safeguarding federal contract information, contract terms, options, funding availability, performance evaluation, and various compliance clauses. It appears to be a generic government contract template with no direct mention of Epstein, his associates, or case-related events. This document is a standard federal government contract clause page detailing compliance requirements for contractors, including Service Contract Labor Standards, Fair Labor Standards Act, and prohibitions on human trafficking. It appears to be part of a larger contract file, but contains no specific case-related information about individuals, events, or locations connected to the Epstein case. This is the second quarter FY 2023 report from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) to Congress on the implementation of the First Step Act of 2018, as directed by the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2023. The report includes a detailed list of vacant BOP positions as of June 15, 2023, and a summary of BOP obligations for FSA implementation through March 31, 2023. It is transmitted via letters from the Justice Management Division to key congressional appropriations subcommittee members. This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) quarterly status report on the implementation of the First Step Act (FSA), covering staffing, program implementation, and inmate statistics for the second quarter of FY 2023 (approximately January-March 2023). It details hiring progress, new evidence-based programs, home confinement and compassionate release statistics, and inmate needs assessments. This document is a collection of administrative materials from the U.S. Department of Justice, primarily concerning the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP). It includes a cover sheet for a BOP vacancies report for FY 2023, transmittal letters to Congressional appropriations subcommittee members, the detailed FY 2023 BOP Vacancies Report itself (listing thousands of vacant positions across all facilities), and several unrelated appended documents including a BOP training guide on conducting searches, a technical proposal from NTT DATA for a 'Staffing Risk Management' project, a monthly security system report, and a Statement of Work for an Employee Assistance Program (EAP). The core BOP report reveals systemic staffing shortages and outlines hiring and retention strategies.

keyFacts: The FBOP is drafting new guidance in response to OIG recommendations on assigning cellmates after suicide watch, ensuring high-risk inmates have cellmates, and standardizing visit approvals during observation periods.
Program Statements are being modified to improve methods for accounting for inmate whereabouts, clarifying Lieutenant round requirements, and enhancing security camera system policies.
The FBOP acknowledges ongoing staffing shortages and is developing an Automated Staffing Tool, analyzing incentive effectiveness, and was granted nation-wide direct-hire authority in May 2024.

Attached analyses (like the Deloitte report and Incentives Playbook) reveal internal concerns: overtime and augmentation hours have increased significantly since 2017, and retention incentives (85% of incentive spending) do not show a strong correlation with reducing staff separations.

The document is primarily a massive, detailed list of vacant positions within the Federal Bureau of Prisons as of June 15, 2023, spanning hundreds of facilities and central office divisions.

The BOP reported $35,655,000 in total obligations to implement the First Step Act through March 31, 2023, with the largest categories being Salary & Training ($16.32M) and Evaluating Programs ($10.826M).
The report is a congressional submission mandated by the Joint Explanatory Statement of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2023, continuing a directive for quarterly updates on FSA implementation.

The transmittal letters indicate the report was cleared by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the Office of the Deputy Attorney General (ODAG), the Office of Legislative Affairs (OLA), and the Associate Law Office (ALO).
The extensive vacancy list suggests significant staffing challenges within the BOP, with thousands of unfilled positions across security, healthcare, administrative, and industrial (UNICOR) roles.
The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) had filled only 29% (301 of 1,030) of its First Step Act (FSA) hiring positions as of March 11, 2023.
The FSA expanded compassionate release, allowing inmates to file motions themselves; in Q2 FY 2023, 86 inmates were released on their own motion versus 5 on BOP's motion.
As of March 31, 2023, 44,120 individuals participated in BOP drug treatment programs, with an estimated 45% of the inmate population meeting criteria for substance use disorder.
A needs assessment of over 127,000 inmates screened identified Substance Use (91,700) and Work (92,919) as the most prevalent needs among the incarcerated population.
The report indicates a significant focus on implementing evidence-based recidivism reduction (EBRR) programs and productive activities (PAs), with 97 total programs in the FSA guide.

The BOP's FY 2023 Vacancies Report lists 6,796 vacant positions across 122 federal facilities as of June 16, 2023, with only 961 positions having a projected hire ('PROJ IN') and 103 having an applicant on a certificate.

The report details extensive efforts to address staffing shortages, including a bureau-wide $10,000 recruitment incentive for correctional officers, retention incentives at chronically understaffed locations, and the use of special pay authorities.

Congress has expressed ongoing concern about BOP vacancies, directing the agency to improve hiring policies, staff facilities at January 2016 levels, and submit detailed reports, citing an 'extremely dangerous environment' for staff and inmates.

An appended technical proposal from NTT DATA outlines a plan to help BOP address Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommendations related to staffing challenges, overtime risk, and Employee Assistance Program (EAP) feedback.

A separate Statement of Work defines requirements for a comprehensive BOP Employee Assistance Program (EAP), highlighting the agency's focus on employee mental health and well-being in a high-stress correctional environment.
